div.p: From Henry Harrington to Redmond Barry
MS 8380, box 600/2 (b), Barry Collection, La Trobe Australian Manuscript Collection, State Library of Victoria.

p.style: font-family: Geneva, Geneva; font-size: 12pt; text-align: end;

div.p:
Transcribed 25/7/97. To proof.
From Harrington, Henry George, 6 November 1866

Presents his respects to Sir Redmond Barry,and hopes that this will reach him before he leaves for Europe. At first you may have forgot me. In the years 1839 to 1842 I was carrying on business as a Chemist at the top of Collins St, a Tenant of J. P. At my death I have the disposal of £2000. Before I left England last Nov 65 I made my will , and have bequestted to you [...] the Library £300. To the Melbourne Hospital £300. I have mentioned your Name as one of the Trustees of those Institutions.
The rest of the letter continues on a new page.

My Will is in the hands of my dear friend Dr Walter Irvine MD 32 Park St Bath. England. Therefore if anything should happen to me, you will know where to apply. I shall be 59 on the next 6 June. Since I have been here from last March I have been miserable & unhappy. I should be happy if I could get back to Melbourne, can you give me anything connected with the Exhibition. I can keep at [writing] & [...] Accounts from [...] [...] Night. Can you spare me a Catalogue and an engraving of the Exhibition Building. I look upon Melbourne, the same as my Birth Place. Most likely I shall leave the remainder of the £2000 [provided] I can find employment, to Parties , and other Institutions in Melbourne. Can you give me any letters of Introduction to any people here. You have known me as a resident and a Brother Mason I hope and trust that you are as active & in good health as when I last saw you at the Exhibition of 1863. All I want is, that I may have employment for my mind, or even for my hands. Pray do give me something to do with your Exhibition. I now conclude my Dear Sir & Brother, wishing you health and happiness for many years to come. Can you get me anything to do under Dr Muller in looking after the Birds, Animals &c. I should then be in my glory, amongst Birds & Animals. Or at any of the Parks. Bring me to Melbourne. You will then have the command of the £2000.

P.S. Would you like to have a copy of my Will.
The envelope with the letter is marked: 'Mr Harrington | Will | Parke Street | Bath. Inside the envelope is written: 'Found in a case (containing seed) in the Verd[un] Gallery. The letter was under a partition with some other papers of no value referring to the seals in the case. The address on the envelope is in Sir Redmond Barry's handwriting. 7th Oct. 1903 [illegible signature]'.
